facts.text: Petitioners were convicted of murder and sentenced to death by Special Tribunal of Hyderabad.

facts.text: Special Tribunal convicted petitioners on 9th, 13th and 14th August 1949 by separate judgments.

anchor.surface_text: They were charged with various offences including murder before a special tribunal established under the regulations promulgated by the Military Governor under the authority of H.E. H. the Nizam and companyvicted and sentenced to death on the 9th, 13th and 14th of August, 1949, by separate judgments.

facts.text: Accused were members of the Communist Party pursuing policy of overthrowing Hyderabad government by violence.

anchor.surface_text: All the accused were charged with being members of the Communist Party wedded to the policy of overthrowing the existing Government at Hyderabad by violence and establishing in its place a companymunist regime.

facts.text: Villagers abducted and murdered on 21st September 1948 for not meeting subscription demands to communist organization.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that they demanded subscriptions towards their companymunist organization and some of the villagers who did number meet their demands were abducted on the 21st of September, 1948, and murdered.

facts.text: Petitioners appealed convictions to Hyderabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners appealed from those judgments to the Hyderabad High Court and the High Court,by its judgments dated the 12th, 13th and 14th December, 1949, respectively, dismissed the appeals.

facts.text: Hyderabad High Court dismissed appeals on 12th, 13th and 14th December 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners appealed from those judgments to the Hyderabad High Court and the High Court,by its judgments dated the 12th, 13th and 14th December, 1949, respectively, dismissed the appeals.

facts.text: Petitioners applied to High Court for certificate to appeal to Judicial Committee on 21st January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners applied to the High Court for a certificate to appeal to the Judicial Committee of the Hyderabad State on the 21st of January, 1950.

facts.text: Nizam issued firman on 23rd November 1949 accepting Constitution of India for Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that H.E.H. the Nizam issued a firman on the 23rd of November, 1949, stating that the proposed Constitution of India was suitable for the government of Hyderabad and he accepted it as the Constitution of the Hyderabad State as one of the States of Part B in the First Schedule.

facts.text: Constitution of India became applicable to Part B States on 26th January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th of January, 1950, the Constitution of India became applicable to the Union of India and the Part B States.

facts.text: Petitions amended to under Article 134 and dismissed by Division Bench of High Court.

facts.text: Hyderabad territory not part of territory of India before 26th January 1950.

facts.text: Article 374(4) abolished Privy Council jurisdiction in Part B States on Constitution commencement.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court has no jurisdiction under Article 136 to grant special leave to appeal from judgments of the Hyderabad High Court dated 12th, 13th and 14th December 1949 as those courts were not within the territory of India at the time.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 136 applies to courts or tribunals in the territory of India; Hyderabad territory not part of India before 26 January 1950; judgments pre-Constitution.

holdings.text: No proceedings transferred to Supreme Court under Article 374(4) as no appeal was pending before Hyderabad Privy Council at Constitution commencement.

anchor.surface_text: Under article 374 (4) on and from the commencement of this Constitution the jurisdiction of the authority functioning as the Privy Council in a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule to entertain and dispose of appeals and petitions from or in respect of any judgment, decree or order of any court within that State ceased,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 374(4) abolishes jurisdiction and transfers only pending matters; facts show no pending proceeding.

holdings.text: Articles of the Constitution must be construed according to their plain natural meaning; cases of hardship should not influence the natural construction.

anchor.surface_text: Articles of the Constitution have to be construed according to their plain natural meaning and cases of hardship should not be brought to bear on the natural construction. Hard cases should not be permitted to make bad law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proper approach to constitutional interpretation rejects hardship arguments; supports textual reading of Article 136.

holdings.text: Legislation, including constitutional provisions, is prima facie prospective and not retrospective unless specifically stated otherwise; right of appeal is substantive requiring explicit grant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Normal rule of interpretation applies; no retrospective jurisdiction over pre-accession foreign state judgments.

holdings.text: Article 135 vests in Supreme Court only the jurisdiction and powers exercisable by Federal Court immediately before Constitution commencement under existing law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 135 succeeds Federal Court jurisdiction under prior laws like Abolition of Privy Council Act; no extension to Hyderabad pre-accession appeals.

holdings.text: Pre-existing rights of appeal from Bombay High Court preserved under Article 135 unlike Hyderabad appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The answer however is that a right to file an appeal from the judgments of the High Court at Bombay in both civil and criminal matters existed under the Civil Procedure Code, Criminal Procedure Code and the Letters Patent of The High Court before the 26th of January, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bombay appeals transferred via existing laws (CPC, CrPC, Letters Patent) and Article 135; Hyderabad lacked such Federal Court jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Article 136 confers a new discretionary jurisdiction to grant special leave from tribunals not previously appealable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Wider words in Article 136 legitimately confer new rights post-Constitution without anomaly.
